tspan.tspan: is a different way of doing control flow in computer
CPS can be used to implement all kinds of advanced
program flow structures without requiring support
from the language - think iterators, coroutines,
Writing code directly in CPS style is hard, but this is
where Nim-CPS comes in. It uses the power of Nim
macros to transform regular code into CPS. This is
- Lift locals from the stack to the environment
- Split the proc at control flow boundaries
- Rewrite the split parts into CPS style functions
The first step in the transformation is moving all the
function parameters and local variables into an
on the stack is now stored
The transformed code has not become any simpler then the original, so what is the point of this all?
The answer lies in the power that comes with this transform: at any time during execution of function on the
the full state of the proc is captured in the continuation object
. This means that the caller can
at any time defer the proc by storing the continuation, and do other work in the mean time - like running other
continuations, waiting for I/O on network sockets or waiting for timers to expire..
With this building block it is possible to build powerful constructs like coroutines, iterators, schedulers for
It is also possible to run continuations in a different order; this allows you to build custom flow control in Nim,
without requiring assistance from the language; constructs like goto, exception handling, defer or finally can all be
of CPS: The split chunks of code
to allow the code to start
Now the code has been transformed into CPS style, the next thing
would be to run it. This is done using a simple construct called a
. The trampoline takes the continuation and
iteratively calls its current function pointer fn(c: Cont): Cont:
The result of the function execution is exactly the same as in the original, untransformed code.

text.tspan: What is the use of all this?
